newsitem.title: UK: BA says strikers could be sacked, sued.
newsitem.headline: BA says strikers could be sacked, sued.

text.p: British Airways Plc said on Saturday it had warned any cabin staff who took part in a planned strike that they could be sacked or sued for damages, a spokesman said.

Iain Burns confirmed a story in the Express on Sunday newspaper which said the airline had sent a warning letter to cabin crew, who last week voted overwhelmingly in favour of striking over a five month pay row.
"Staff have been informed that striking could result in them being dismissed or being sued for damages," Burns said by telephone, describing the measures as a last option.
"Clearly we don't want to do that. But management resolve is strong. We don't want our customers to suffer," he added.
The T&G union acting for British Airways staff said a meeting to decide whether unionised cabin crew should strike and for how long would be held on Monday.
The airline faces a separate threat on Monday when unions will also publish the result of a second strike ballot of 9,000 BA ground staff.

BA has already placed its operations on red alert to cope with the strike threat. It said earlier this week it had retrained non T&G-affiliated staff in other duties and was willing to make external appointments.
If action goes ahead, strike breakers will be offered payments of 75 pounds ($125) in cash per day for taxis, hotel accommodation and coach services to break through picket lines.
T&G leader Bill Morris, writing in the Express on Sunday, accused BA chief executive Robert Ayling of acting like bullying 19th century mill owner. Burns dismissed the charge.
"Would a 19th century mill owner share 94 million pounds ($150 million) with its staff as we have done this year as part of our profit-share scheme?" he asked. ($ = 0.601 British Pounds)
